header_summary:
The Quantum‑Resistant Address Migration Protocol (QRAMP) introduces a novel approach to enhance post-quantum security by quarantining legacy Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) through a two-phase commit and spend flow. This method, detailed with a [design note](https://github.com/bnavf/bitcoinqp/blob/main/two_phase_destination_commitment.md) and [diagram](https://github.com/bnavf/bitcoinqp/blob/main/two_phase_destination_commitment.svg), aims to prevent destination substitution attacks, ensuring that legacy UTXOs remain spendable while mitigating potential security vulnerabilities. The proposal also includes user experience considerations, such as fee sponsorship and off-chain commitment authorization, addressing practical and technical challenges in its implementation.

The release of Bitcoin Core v30.2, as announced on the [Bitcoin Core website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.2/), brings significant upgrades including new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements. Highlighting the collaborative effort behind this release, contributors such as Ava Chow, brunoerg, and others are acknowledged, though an oversight excluded jestory and davidgumberg from the credits despite their crucial contributions, spotlighting the need for a more inclusive acknowledgment system for all forms of contribution.

Hornet UTXO(1) represents a significant advancement in Bitcoin client technology, as part of the Hornet Node project aiming for high-performance consensus validation. This lock-free, highly concurrent UTXO database, capable of revalidating the entire mainnet chain significantly faster than Bitcoin Core, is detailed in T. Sharp's "Hornet Node: A Declarative, Executable Specification of Bitcoin Consensus," available in [HTML](https://hornetnode.org/paper.html) and [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2509.15754) formats. The project invites feedback and collaboration to further develop this efficient consensus validation mechanism.

Lastly, a collaborative potential is highlighted between Bithoven's work and a project focused on formalizing state-bound assets on Bitcoin through the 'W' protocol. This collaboration could leverage Bithoven’s static analyzer to address challenges related to Schnorr Introspection and MAST-binding covenants, as detailed in the [OPI-003 document](https://github.com/The-Universal-BRC-20-Extension/OPI/blob/19f9ab66ebbda1a4b210d7b110ba2af506c1/OPI/OPI-003-W.md), suggesting a synergistic approach to advancing Bitcoin's capabilities in handling state-bound assets.

recent_posts.title: QRAMP addition: Alternative to legacy freeze: “quarantine-mode” legacy spends via two-phase destination commitment
recent_posts.summary:
- QRAMP proposes a quarantine mode for legacy UTXOs to remain spendable post-quantum.
- The approach includes a two-phase commit and spend flow, aiming to secure transactions.
- It challenges consensus enforcement without historical lookups and suggests fee sponsorship for user ease.

recent_posts.summary:

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.2rc1 Released
recent_posts.summary:

recent_posts.title: Hornet UTXO(1): A custom, constant-time, highly parallel UTXO database
recent_posts.summary:
- Hornet UTXO(1) is a new database enhancing Bitcoin's consensus validation through advanced C++ programming.
- It significantly outperforms Bitcoin Core in revalidating the mainnet chain, showcasing remarkable efficiency and speed.
- The project encourages community feedback and is detailed in T. Sharp's paper on Bitcoin consensus specification.

today_in_history_posts.summary: - Rusty Russell inquired about a heuristic's validity post-Taproot, receiving a negative.  - Taproot maintains the privacy of private channels against a specific tracing method.  - This method tracks channel ownership by analyzing UTXO lineage to link them to node IDs.
